text: I wasn't aware of Betmover, betangel obviously has it's own high level scripting language which is pretty easy to use, so I agree with Mo a large influx of money, Peter made a fantastic move in intergrating it in their software but yes has taken rather a long time :slightly_smiling_face:

text: From what I have seen (which is not a lot) the BA does not have a race visualiser of the GPS whereas Betmover does so I would still imagine that for someone who is a manual "trader" for IP races the Betmover would still be more useful. For people who want the automation BA better probably but I think there will be a lot of disappointed end users when they realise that GPS is not the golden ticket that some think it is.

text: Someone posted a link on the BetAngel forum to a Telegram group for Betmover.  I had a look and there were about 45 people in there.  Whether they're all active or there are more people using it that aren't in the group I've no idea.

text: It's interesting reading about the issues people are having with it

elements.text: It's interesting reading about the issues people are having with it

text:
I picked a random post from the Telegram room:

"I could easily win £100 a day when gps is on point that would be great second in come. Even if i won £30 a day i could pay my mortgage. But  being disciplined is hard"

For context, six minutes earlier, the same user posted:

"Lost a fortune tonight :sleepy:. Shame its like that you lose confidence in the software. I have thought about winning a set amout a day then stopping but i cant do it i just keep on betting"

As <@UUE6E1LA1> said in his post, GPS is not the golden ticket (although for some, it could quickly become a different coloured ticket)

elements.text:
I picked a random post from the Telegram room:

"I could easily win £100 a day when gps is on point that would be great second in come. Even if i won £30 a day i could pay my mortgage. But  being disciplined is hard"

For context, six minutes earlier, the same user posted:

"Lost a fortune tonight

. Shame its like that you lose confidence in the software. I have thought about winning a set amout a day then stopping but i cant do it i just keep on betting"

As
said in his post, GPS is not the golden ticket (although for some, it could quickly become a different coloured ticket)

text: This kind of mindset is so common. Failure to realise that if something provides you with an edge you want to be involved in as many markets as you possibly can, not stopping when you have made 30 pop for the day. Unbelievable and yet all too prevalent.

elements.text: This kind of mindset is so common. Failure to realise that if something provides you with an edge you want to be involved in as many markets as you possibly can, not stopping when you have made 30 pop for the day. Unbelievable and yet all too prevalent.

text: Don’t have an account so can’t check but does it seem like anyone is making money manually off the data?

text: I used to make a few pennies with my poor mans version of betmover that I wrote at the very start of my GPS time. But only looking for very specific things to happen and even then you could get it wrong. Fair play to anyone who can do that given the quirks of the data. Fair play to anyone with the patience to do manual trading full stop to be honest - I find it so so boring.

text: Does anyone know how BF round their cancellation / placement / match timestamps? Seems that in APING and the stream we only get 1 second resolution but does anyone know if that timestamp is rounded normally or floored or bumped to next second?

elements.text: Does anyone know how BF round their cancellation / placement / match timestamps? Seems that in APING and the stream we only get 1 second resolution but does anyone know if that timestamp is rounded normally or floored or bumped to next second?

text: <@U02MA2XF6E9> has joined the channel
I don't know but did you see this thread? <https://betfairlightweight.slack.com/archives/C02J4CBA0H5/p1634896059330300>

attachments.fallback:
[October 22nd, 2021 2:47 AM] gd: Would Betfair be willing to provide accurate(ish - down to millisecond precision) internal timestamps in responses and in the stream?
1. When I send a bet in-play, for example in horse racing, I get a 'pending' response, but this response doesn't include the timestamp that the order was received at the Betfair server. This timestamp must exist in order for Betfair's tech to know in which sequence all orders were received. It would be great to have this timestamp included in the pending response, so that I can measure my latency "from door to door" accurately.
2. On the market data stream we receive a 'publishTime' which is presumably the time at which the matching engine cycle finished. It would also be useful to have a field that represents the time at which the matching engine cycle began. This would enable me to look back at the logs and say: OK, my order didn't arrive in time to make it into this matching cycle which began at T1, so it was delayed a bit longer and had to wait for the next one, which began at time T2.
attachments.text:
Would Betfair be willing to provide accurate(ish - down to millisecond precision) internal timestamps in responses and in the stream?
1. When I send a bet in-play, for example in horse racing, I get a 'pending' response, but this response doesn't include the timestamp that the order was received at the Betfair server. This timestamp must exist in order for Betfair's tech to know in which sequence all orders were received. It would be great to have this timestamp included in the pending response, so that I can measure my latency "from door to door" accurately.
2. On the market data stream we receive a 'publishTime' which is presumably the time at which the matching engine cycle finished. It would also be useful to have a field that represents the time at which the matching engine cycle began. This would enable me to look back at the logs and say: OK, my order didn't arrive in time to make it into this matching cycle which began at T1, so it was delayed a bit longer and had to wait for the next one, which began at time T2.

This timestamp must exist in order for Betfair's tech to know in which sequence all orders were received. It would be great to have this timestamp included in the pending response, so that I can measure my latency "from door to door" accurately.

On the market data stream we receive a 'publishTime' which is presumably the time at which the matching engine cycle finished. It would also be useful to have a field that represents the time at which the matching engine cycle began. This would enable me to look back at the logs and say: OK, my order didn't arrive in time to make it into this matching cycle which began at T1, so it was delayed a bit longer and had to wait for the next one, which began at time T2.
I don't know but did you see this thread?

text: Thanks Mo. Going forward it is not a problem for me but for quite a while I was polling listCurrentOrders before finally implementing order stream - hence the question to try and slightly improve the accuracy of the timestamps I have historically.

elements.text: Thanks Mo. Going forward it is not a problem for me but for quite a while I was polling listCurrentOrders before finally implementing order stream - hence the question to try and slightly improve the accuracy of the timestamps I have historically.
